posts.sub: Why is it impossible to find a girlfriend?
posts.com:
There are some men (like myself) who are intuitively unattractive to women. We foolishly fall for the improover memes, thinking that doing "xyz" will increase our chances of finding a girlfriend but it makes no difference. You either have "it" or you don't. That's why there's a percentage of men who can attract women without even trying.
>just to talk women
No point approaching women who are not interested in you.
>how do you know they're not interested?
There's a thing called body language. Non-verbal communication can be more powerful than words. When a woman is interested, she will send you signals, consciously or otherwise. It's then up to the man to respond to those signals. If she's not sending you any signals, then chances are she isn't interested. You can talk to her if you want, but you'll only be confirming what you already know. It's just humiliating and a waste of time.
>try tinder and dating sites
It's not like online dating is much better. If anything it's an even greater exercise in futility. Take flattering photos, work on an engaging profile, only to be swiped past by 99% of women, with 1% being bots lmao.
It's not pessimistic, it's not defeatist — it's realistic.

When I met my girl, we asked a lot of questions that related to our own interests and areas of compatibility. Many of these were typical things like discussions on music, career goals, passions. When she indicated she was into art then I asked a lot of questions about it. Likewise she asked a lot of things about me. Getting to know each other happened well before flirting and romance. We became friends first, and were both adults out of college who met due to shared interests. Often those are the best places, bonding with people over things that you enjoy. I had many long lasting friendships arise from being a nerd who placed Dungeons and Dragons at a tabletop gaming store each week.

If you are volunteering at a dog shelter, then perhaps you talk about dogs. The shared interest bit is actually a really beneficial thing so long as you are interested too. If I was at a shelter, I'd ask a lot of questions on the actual tasks, but then probably ask people what their favorite breeds were, their experiences with dogs at home, things like that.

>no point in churches... no women there
When was the last time you were in one?

Age greatly changes the rate of healing. Usually limb lengthening is less traumatic and more easily healed with children. That said, sacrificing your prime years for recovery seems like a bad bet. I can't entirely blame you because I had thoughts about surgeries like that too when I was younger until I realized what a trap it was mentally.

I'm below average height. For a long time I blamed external reasons like height for a lack of success with women and life in general. However, I have known people who had taller girlfriends and understand that most average women are shorter than most "short" men. Time, wisdom, and experience really help to put things into a proper perspective.

Fuck, it isn't about liking aspects of yourself. I'm sure 90% of people would like to be taller or have a slightly bigger dick, but it is about accepting your positive aspects as well as your shortcomings. Insecurity is the cancer, not your height. As soon as I really started to become more comfortable with the limitations I possessed, I found myself far more successful with relationships and romance... communication in general.

In the end, the focus on our shortcomings is almost a narcissism because it is so focused on ourselves, as if we were the center of the universe. You box people out because you can only think about facets of yourself. At least that is what I did.

You are worth companionship. You are worthy of love and compassion. It isn't something that is contingent on height or another physical attribute. Don't sell yourself down a road where you think that you have to buy your own worth.

I once had a girlfriend, back when I was 15. It was my first true love, and my first friend. We got really close really fast, specially for me. I didn't know how people really interacted, what was right and wrong, so this was all really new to me. My parents were divorced by then, so I didn't talk to my father, and my mother was always at work. I was raised by my grandparents.
We dated for a couple of months, but it felt really intense for me, and I committed a ton of mistakes. At that time, I had this wish that at one point, someone would come into my life and fix everything. Someone who would love me and make everything better, and I pegged all of that pressure into her without my knowing.
At the time I also started self harm with some cutter I had in my scattered room. For some reason I sometimes sent her pictures of it. Maybe I wanted her attention, or I don't know, I am a fucking idiot, so I can't really tell you what my reasoning was. As anyone would be, she was worried, and I loved it. I liked her attention because it felt like reassurance that she cared about me, even though no attention was ever enough for me.
I also trauma dumped on her a lot, to the point that it was hurting her own mental health, which was already in the dumps. I am selfish, and I hurt her consistently, without really knowing. Or maybe I knew and didn't care. It was the first time I could freely talk to someone about how I felt, so I went and told her my own thoughts as raw as I could. Maybe I also liked the attention and worry I got when she heard me talk about how much I wanted to kill myself.
Even if I tried to help her with her issues, I somehow always ended up making it about myself. You know… talking about how her parents were shitty, and I would somehow end up getting so pissed off about how shitty they were treating her that I had a panic attack, so she would end up helping ME, rather than me helping her.

I also used her to hurt myself. When she broke up, I yelled at my phone and cried, asking why, even though I already knew, and could probably list off more than a 100 things I did wrong. Don't switch into an antagonistic reading of this post, but you sound very whiny. You just whinge. I haven't read all your posts, but you don't even suggest a solution, a passion. I don't believe you can't hypothetically come up with a goal in life. Goals and passions don't have to be some innate quality, it can be constructed, you can "convince" yourself to regard a mild interest as a worthy goal.
The goal doesn't need to be work, education or money related. I almost feel dirty for having to point out this -- to my eyes -- self-evident rejection of a wagedrone mindset. Maybe your goal is moving to Japan, whatever.
But you don't even try to conceptualize and, blogging here, articulate a possible concrete goal.
If you can't think of one, no one can help you. Visualize your life as a trajectory: if you keep doing what you are right now, you keep doing what you are doing right now. You said you aren't happy like this. Ergo, you need to input alternate target coordinates.
Yeah yeah I know "at least others can come up with these kinds of goals as well", "I know I am not ESPECIALLY miserable, but from my perspective, the difference to a 'true/cliched' miserable state doesn't matter".
Shut up. Shut your internal monologuing. This is literally just ruminating. It accomplishes nothing. It's the hallmark of the 110 IQ word-thinker type (I am not trying to insult you). You don't NEED to monologue, or quasi-monologue by blogging here (I am not saying you should stop seeking this kind of dialogue about your problems -- or continue).
Also, I don't think what you expressed truly strikes me as ADHD (due to lack of information -- you sound like a rather generic NEET case, currently), but you might as well try to get diagnosed. I think at the very least you are such a borderline case that wouldn't need meds (especially if you don't have aspirations in very involving academic subjects), but with them you could be easily pushed over the edge to become successful.

Told my affair partner I was divorcing - she was shocked. I think she feels some responsibility for it although I explained to her that it was mostly a disconnect in the relationship that has been confirmed over a bunch of marriage counseling sessions. Certainly the affair layered on another intense amount of pain but the fundamental disconnects have been present for a while.

AP has said for a few weeks that she thought we should stop talking due to my wife and I still trying to figure things out and that she needed time. She would go a few days and then was always the one to break no-contact and reach out to me again and start talking for a few days. She feels a lot of pressure from friends and family that she shouldn't speak to me. She says she feels so anxious and confused - between what her friends say, what she feels about me, about what I say. She tells me she loves me and is happy with me but feels anxious and wrong after we talk.

It's kinda frustrating to me since I'm a bit of a realist and feel that relationships wither and die if left unattended - even the best ones. So taking time just makes me feel that this is an opportunity lost. She doesn't feel that way. But I intend to respect what she says she wants as hard as that is.

Of course the grief of this loss is compounded with the discomfort of the transition at home, which becomes more tenuous daily. posts.sub: Trouble falling asleep... but it's NOT insomnia
posts.com:
Okay, so to be clear I do NOT have insomnia, although I frequently tell people I do to save explaining. If I lay down and intend to go to sleep, I fall asleep within 5 minutes almost every time, and literally never wake up in the middle of the night, I sleep right through.

So you might say, no problem! But big problem. I fail to make the decision to go to sleep.

I think tonight I am having an epiphany about the cause. It's because I just want to "feel something". Of course I have been depressed for about the last 10 years (30M), so that's part of it, part of it is getting stuck in an almost manic state of "gotta pack in some more fun", or "gotta read this book/manga/whatever", which is another way of "feeling something". I suspect this is easier at night vs the day for practical reasons, but also I'm sure there's a feeling of wanting to pack the day with "fun" to an unreasonable degree.

So all of this to say, neat, great, now I understand the "why", but I have no actual solution to how to go to bed more on time. Try to double down on doing more fulfilling things during the day? Special type of self-talk to pop some nighttime delusion? I literally don't know. There sadly does not seem to be a correlation with exercise, so that's out. It's just the decision to go to bed that's hard. help pls

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28362995
the night time and the circadium rhythms where your stress hormone spikes during sleep
so you literally avoid that feeling unconsciously by delaying it

you have 'time' at night. there's a sense of freedom and little pace

some people are just born to be night owls and others arent
we get into the habit early and set it bad forever
you can change though

you just have to fully rationalise the idea that what youre doing is not worth it and should have been done during the day

either do it earlier or later next time. and stuff like scrolling or mindless browsing is just trying to avoid the spike in stress during sleep

night sleep, because theres so much to expect tomorrow, is not good sleep for anxious
on the job sleep, when you should be doing it, that's somehow bliss

Im in the Same place OP, if havent done it by now is because it would destroy my parents ( almost nobody around me know about my problems including them).

The way I started to cope with it was just to accept that I was never going to be happy, or have a fullfillment life where I could achive something I would really want. Then started to focus in the things I love like crafting, hanging out with friends, exercise reading But most importantly

nature (I study biology and since 4/5 years ago I walk like 25-30 km across the forest each saturday, moreover ive dedicated those years to Irepopulate areas with bushes and trees I have helped to born and grow) This activity makes me think Im not a total waste, and when I see my little trees growing I feel a joy I cant describe.

Some years ago I started to think about my mental state as war of trenches. each adavance is very hard but in every inch of "land" I take against myself I make a trench and I refuse to give back that victory to my depression. You have to create your trench and start advancing, It doesnt care if it is slower or faster, or even if you loose, you have to keep advancing no matter the pain or cost.

posts.sub: How do I act/behave on a date?
posts.com: It's a casual sort of thing. Give me as much advice as possible/as you are willing to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28350442
Eye contact 80% of the time
No edgy jokes
Be a good listener, try to remember the little details they can be useful later and make you more trustworthy
Try not to talk too much about yourself, you should use your experiences/stories as a way to make your date share about themselves.
Don't project too much, things most likely won't go the way you planned them in your head and that can make you choke/stutter, live in the moment.
Don't be afraid to lightly and jokingly tease them around the middle/later part of the date.
Don't be too pressed, take it easy and slow, if you go too fast they might get creeped.
That's honestly all I could think about, but the best advice is to just enjoy yourself.

>>28363580
>But that's how I feel even if I like the guy.
There is a basic imbalance in this situation. If a girl asks a guy out and he's not interested, the absolute worst that can possibly happen is that the situation is a bit awkward. Even if he's not interested, he'll be flattered.

If a guy asks a girl out and really messes it up, she may end up physically *frightened* of him. That's on a whole different level in terms of situations you want to avoid happening. In a *really* extreme case, if he fucks it up badly enough, the guy might even end up being reported to the authorities for harassment, might get fired or expelled from college, or whatever.

So, I don't mean to minimise the pain of being shy; I'm shy myself and I know what it's like; but really and truly, in terms of what can go wrong, a guy asking a girl out is in a completely different league from the problems you have to deal with. If you expect guys to ask you out instead of you asking them because you're too chicken, you're going to make them feel approximately a million times more scared than you feel.

posts.com:
You can move to a city like Austin Texas, or another "leftwing" city with lots of public assistance for the poor and homeless. Austin has 2 shelters downtown, right next to eachother. You can stay overnight in both. Salvation Army is your best bet because if you skip a night or show up late each night your bed is given away. Lots of drug addicts and alcoholics cant adhere to that policy so there are always open beds. You show up in their lobby on 7th or 8th street in the morning and wait to meet with a counselor and get set up.

You dont need anything. There's a soup kitchen real close to that building for lunch. People stop by that area downtown and donate food all the time. Lots of churches feed people throughout the week. Plus its a fun city. I would just get a plane ticket and fly down to Austin. Then there's a bus stop at the airport that will take you right downtown. Easy peasy.
